title: Drunk man drives car into crowd of protesters in Chile, kills two
text:
A drunk motorist plowed into a crowd of protesters and killed two people, including a four-year-old boy, and injured at least 20 in southern Chile on Tuesday night.

Surveillance footage showed the moment the 34-year-old man rammed his car into the group, who were defying a curfew to protest at a street intersection in San Pedro de la Paz.

According to Chilean outlet Cooperativa, police said the driver registered a blood alcohol level of 1.49, almost double the legal limit of 0.8.

The driver, whose name was not released to local media, was beaten by the protesters before he was arrested.

CCTV camera in San Pedro de la Paz, Chile, captures the moment the driver hit the group of protesters

Protesters gather around the vehicle that was flipped over by an angry crowd after its driver plowed into a group of people, killing two and injuring at least 20

Bystanders who were defying a curfew tend to a woman who was struck by a vehicle Tuesday night

At least 15 people have died across the South American country as a result of six consecutive days of demonstrations.

Students took to the street of Santiago last Monday in response to President Sebastián Piñera's proposal to increase the subway fare by 4 percent.

They mobbed several metro stations, jumping turnstiles in a fare-dodging protest before demonstrations turned deadly during the weekend as more than half of the capital city's subway stations were set on fire and local businesses were looted and burned.

Piñera declared a state of emergency last Friday and the following day announced that he would no longer go through with his plan to increase the subway fare from $1.12 to $1.16.

The capital city's subway system, which serves an average of 2.4 million daily passengers, suffered almost $300 million in damages to 78 of its 136 stations.

The police in the Chilean city of San Pedro de la Paz said the driver of a vehicle which plowed over protesters Tuesday night had a blood alcohol level of 1.48, nearly double the limit of 0.8

Demonstrators attack a vehicle after its driver plowed over a crowd, killing two people, including a four-year-old boy

A demonstrator uses a slingshot at Plaza Italia on Tuesday during the fifth straight day of protest with a small fire in the background

The unrest has spread nationwide, fueled by simmering frustration by many Chileans who say that they are not sharing in the advances of a country that is one of Latin America's wealthiest.

In a move to quell the violent protesters, President Piñera has placed the military in charge of security in the city of six million following arson attacks and looting.

Soldiers patrolling the streets in Santiago have stirred up memories of the military dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, which ended in 1990.

A crowd of people clamber on a monument in Santiago yesterday, many of them holding what appear to be musical instruments and others waving flags and placards

A masked man throws something into a blazing fire in Plaza Italia in Santiago, where thousands of people have been protesting in recent days

Riot police used tear gas and water cannons to break up marches by rock-throwing demonstrators in several parts of Santiago on Tuesday.

The violence has damaged shops, banks and metro stations, and police and soldiers were yesterday guarding shoppers, who formed long lines for milk and other food products at the stores which remained open.

Piñera met Tuesday with the leaders of some of Chile's opposition parties as he sought a way to stem the country's worst violence in decades.

About half of country's 16 regions are under an emergency decree and some are under military curfew.
